awd_titl_txt: Machine Learning, Reservoir Computing, and Nonlinear Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to obtain basic understanding of the mechanisms by which machine learning can predict the evolution of nonlinear dynamical systems, and to explore how to use this knowledge to improve existing machine learning prediction and devise new capabilities.  Achieving this goal would advance our understanding of a host of potential important applications that can be described mathematically by dynamical systems, ranging from gene therapies to weather prediction.  Graduate students are engaged in the research of the project.

The investigator uses concepts from nonlinear dynamics and chaos theory to obtain understanding of when, how, and why machine learning techniques are effective in predicting the evolution of the state of a dynamical system, including consideration of dynamical systems that are large and complex (e.g., spatially based systems).  In addition, he considers the issue of "climate preservation," by which is meant the ability of machine learning tools to replicate the long-term ergodic properties of a dynamical system about which little is known, from measurements of time series of its state evolution.  The investigator uses this ability to formulate machine learning tools for determining ergodic properties (e.g., Lyapunov exponent spectra) of the dynamics of the unknown system.  Graduate students are engaged in the research of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This progects goals are to investigate the use of machine learning for the purpose of carrying out tasks in the field of nonlinear dynamics, as wells for the purpose of using nonlinear dynamics to elucidate and improve the working of ML. Below we summarize the main outcomes of our work.

 Prediction of nonstationary dynamical systems. By a nonstationary dynamical system we mean one in which the process determining the dynamics of system states themselves change with time. (An example is the evolution of weather as a result of climate change.) Considering prediction of temporal state behavior from past time series data, this task seems particularly challenging in that the past data is for a different dynamics than the future. We have shown that, by employing new techniques that we have developed, ML can  be very effective for this class of challenging tasks. This work has been reported in a published paper.

   Inference of network connection topology from measured nodal time series. Here we consider a situation where measured time series data from a system formed by interconnecting many dynamical units is available, but dynamics of the individual units and their connection network are unknown. The task --- essentially an 'inverse problem' --- is to infer the connection network from the data. We address this problem by first using the data to train an ML prediction system to predict how the states of all the dynamical units (network nodes) change over a short time interval. We next examine the internal learned ML parameters, which we then use  to determine causality relationships between the nodes, from which we extract the desired knowledge of the commection network. This technique, along with validation tests on numerical simulations, has been reported in a published paper. In a subsequent published paper, we have extended this work to links with time delays in the propagation of signals along the network links, and, in collaboration with experimenters, we have applied and validated our method on data from networks of interacting laser devices. Our most recent work in this general area arose from tests of our ML link inference ideas on neuronal data. Specifically, we considered time series of the activity of the motor neurons of C. elegans worms. We found that the avaulable time series data had features that presented problems for carrying out the desired network inference task --- e.g., observational noise, low sampling rates, partial state measurement, etc. As this type of data is common, we then turned to the problem of extraction network topological properties when such nonideal data properties are present. Our results on this important problem are now almost ready for submission for publication.

   Predicting the evolution of network systems of dynamical nodes. Here we consider the problem of forecasting the future evolution of large dynamical networks from data. In particular, straightforward use of recent ML forecasting techniques can become problematic when the network size is large and is further complicated when the network connections are unknown. We have formulated and tested ML methods for this problem. Our method utilizes many relatively small ML systems independently trained in parallel. This work has been published.

   Systems subjected to dynamical noise. In this project we utilize ML to analize dynamics of systems subjected to dynamical noise describable by  "stochastic differential equations." Buolding on our previous work, we attempt to deduce characterizations of these systems from the time series they produce, as well as those of the learned ML systems resulting from training on such data. Although substantial progress has been made, this work will continue past the conclusion of the present grant.
